questions.text: A 32-year-old woman visits the gynecologist with complaint of vaginal and vulvar itching, a slightly watery discharge and pain with intercourse. On examination the vaginal pH was estimated as 4.4. Microscopic examination was performed on some Gram-stained dis charge material. The observation was similar to below. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Candidiasis. Explanation of the Correct Answer: This 32-year-old woman presents with vaginal and vulvar itching, watery discharge, and dyspareunia (pain during intercourse). Her vaginal pH is 4.4, which remains within the normal acidic range (3.8–4.5). Microscopic examination (Gram stain) reveals yeast cells and pseudohyphae, confirming the diagnosis of vulvovaginal candidiasis (VVC). Candida species, primarily Candida albicans, is a part of the normal vaginal flora but can overgrow when the vaginal environment is altered, such as in: Antibiotic use (reduces normal lactobacilli) Pregnancy or hormonal changes Diabetes mellitus Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, corticosteroid use) Key Features of Vulvovaginal Candidiasis (VVC): Symptoms: Intense vulvar and vaginal itching Thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge (though sometimes watery) Dyspareunia (painful intercourse) Erythema, swelling, and excoriation of the vulva Vaginal pH: Normal (≤ 4.5) Microscopy (Gram stain/KOH prep): Budding yeast, pseudohyphae, or true hyphae Treatment: Topical azoles (clotrimazole, miconazole) for mild cases Oral fluconazole for more severe or recurrent infections Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) – Incorrect BV is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis and other anaerobes, resulting in a fishy-smelling, thin grayish-white vaginal discharge. Vaginal pH is > 4.5, which is higher than normal due to loss of lactobacilli. Microscopy would show clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria), not budding yeast or pseudohyphae. (C) Chlamydial Vaginitis – Incorrect Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis, vaginal discharge, and dysuria, but it typically does not cause significant itching or a thick discharge. Microscopy does not show yeast or hyphae; instead, nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) are required for diagnosis. Vaginal pH is usually unchanged or slightly elevated. (D) Trichomoniasis – Incorrect Trichomonas vaginalis, a motile protozoan, causes yellow-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge, not the thick white discharge seen in candidiasis. Strawberry cervix (petechiae on cervix) may be present. Vaginal pH is elevated (> 4.5), whereas in this case, it is 4.4 (normal). Microscopy (wet mount) shows motile, flagellated protozoa, not yeast.

questions.text: A 40 year old farmer presents to the hospital with complaints of nasal obstruction, purulent rhinorrhea, odynophagia and a lesion inside his mouth. Histopathology of a biopsy specimen stained with methenamine silver is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Paracoccidioidomycosis Explanation of the Correct Answer: This 40-year-old farmer presents with nasal obstruction, purulent rhinorrhea, odynophagia (painful swallowing), and an oral lesion, suggesting a chronic granulomatous infection affecting the upper respiratory tract and oral mucosa. The histopathology of the biopsy specimen stained with methenamine silver confirms the presence of Paracoccidioides spp., the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis (South American blastomycosis). Key features of Paracoccidioidomycosis: Causative organism: Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (a dimorphic fungus endemic to South and Central America) Risk group: Farmers, rural workers, and individuals exposed to soil and plant material Symptoms: Chronic mucocutaneous and upper respiratory lesions Oral ulcers with a "mulberry-like" appearance Pulmonary symptoms (cough, dyspnea) in severe cases Histology (Methenamine Silver Stain): Characteristic "pilot’s wheel" or "Mickey Mouse" appearance due to multiple budding yeast cells arranged around a central mother cell Treatment: Itraconazole (mild to moderate cases) Amphotericin B (severe cases) Explanation of Incorrect Options: (A) Blastomycosis – Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is another dimorphic fungus, but it primarily affects the lungs and can disseminate to the skin and bones, rather than causing mucosal lesions and nasal obstruction. Histology shows broad-based budding yeast, which is distinct from the "pilot’s wheel" appearance of Paracoccidioides. Endemic in North America (Ohio and Mississippi River Valleys), not South America. (C) Histoplasmosis – Incorrect Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, which primarily affects the lungs and reticuloendothelial system (e.g., liver, spleen, bone marrow). Mucosal involvement is rare and usually occurs in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV/AIDS). Histology shows small, oval yeast cells inside macrophages, not the multiple budding "pilot’s wheel" pattern seen in Paracoccidioides. Endemic in Ohio and Mississippi River Valleys and parts of Central America. (D) Leishmaniasis – Incorrect Leishmania spp. is a protozoan parasite, not a fungus. Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis (caused by L. braziliensis) can cause oral and nasal mucosal lesions, but histopathology would show amastigotes inside macrophages, not fungal budding yeast. Transmitted by sandfly bites, not inhalation.
